snippet: The families of two Afghan men experienced the trauma of their deaths, the joy of hearing they were alive, then the shock of a government demand that it get its money back.
abstract: Families of Afghan soldiers Noor ul-Haq and Imamuddin Ibrahimkhel are joyful to discover men, who had been declared dead by army and buried, are in fact still alive; are asked, however, to pay back $2,300 given them by government as compensation, making happy event stressful, as money has been spent.

byline.contributor: Ahmad Shakib contributed reporting from Kabul, and an employee of The New York Times from Helmand Province.

lead_paragraph: The families of two Afghan men experienced the trauma of their deaths, the joy of hearing they were alive, then the shock of a government demand that it get its money back.

headline.main: Found Alive, Soldiers Are Told: You Owe Us for Burials
headline.print_headline: Declared Dead in Afghan War, Then Living With Funeral Debt
